LAND RECLAMATION WORKS IN PUNGGOL
(Progress)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development (a) what progress has been made with regard to land reclamation works in Punggol; (b) when such works will be completed and at what cost; and (c) what development plans are in hand.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, land reclamation works in Punggol, west of Sungei Serangoon, commenced in October 1983. To-date, 95% of the works has been completed and 140 hectares out of the total 145 hectares of foreshore has been reclaimed.

Column: 909



    The Punggol project is expected to be completed by end 1987 at an estimated cost of $37 million.

    The reclaimed land will be part of the future Punggol New Town.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Hon. Minister indicate to the House what other lands are to be reclaimed in the Punggol area? When will such works take place and whether he will make available a copy of the plan indicating the works to be carried out to the House?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, in addition to the area that I have mentioned, there will be lands reclaimed west of Punggol Point between Sungei Punggol and the Punggol Point, as well as the land between what is known as Coney Island and the mainland. The total land to be reclaimed between Sungei Punggol and Sungei Serangoon will be 373 hectares. This will form part of the future Punggol New Town. There will also be other reclamation in the vicinity to the east of Sungei Serangoon where there will be another area of 210 hectares that will be reclaimed. We have not yet decided what this land will be used for but it will be used for future development. The area between Sungei Punggol and Sungei Serangoon will be reclaimed between 1987 and 1989 and the other area which is east of Sungei Serangoon will be reclaimed in the early 1990s.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Could the Hon. Minister indicate what is the total estimated cost of these additional works? And he has not answered the third part of my question, that is, whether he will make available a copy of the plan of works to the House?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I certainly will give a plan (Cols. 1019 - 1020) for the information of the House. The total cost of the additional reclamation works would be in the region of $150 million.

ADMISSION OF JUNIOR COLLEGE AND PRE-U
CENTRE STUDENTS INTO THE UNIVERSITIES
(Figures)


    4. Dr Ow Chin Hock asked the Minister for Education (a) how many per cent of the 1984 and 1985 cohorts of junior college students were admitted into the two local Universities; and (b) how many per cent of

Column: 911

the 1983 and 1984 cohorts of Pre-University centre students were admitted into the two local Universities.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    54% and 55% of the junior college final-year students in 1984 and 1985 respectively were admitted to the two universities in the following year.

    18% and 16% of the Pre-U centre final-year students in 1983 and 1984 respectively were admitted to the two universities in the following year.

    Sir, these figures taken as a whole could be misunderstood and therefore I would like, with your permission, to elaborate a little on them. From the average it appears that junior college students and Pre-U centre students have a 50% chance of going on to university. But this does not mean that every junior college student or Pre-U centre student has a one in two chance of joining university. It depends very much on what grades they obtained at their 'A' levels. Sir, we have found from past experience that '0' level results of students is a reliable predictor of how well they would do at their 'A' levels. Therefore those who do very well at '0' level, with five to 10 points for their best five subjects, do go on to do well at 'A' levels and have a high chance of going on to the university. But those with average '0' level results, between 15 and 20 points, do not do so well at 'A' level generally, and only one in five or less go on to the university; 80% do not. Students with average '0' level results, namely, 15 to 20 points, should instead consider other alternatives such as joining the polytechnics where their chances of completing their course will be much higher. In the case of the polytechnics, students with 15 to 20 points have more than a 90% chance of completing their diploma.

     Dr Ow Chin Hock (Leng Kee): Supplementary question, Sir. How many per cent of the cohort of students had 15 to 20 points?

FEEDBACK UNIT
(Performance)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chew Heng Ching:

    7. To ask the Minister for Community Development if he is satisfied with the work performed by the Feedback Unit.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Mr Chew.

     Encik Ibrahim Othman (Tanah Merah): Question No. 7, Sir.

     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, I am satisfied with the work of the Feedback Unit. Let me elaborate.

    As Members may recall, the Feedback Unit was set up in March 1985 to provide an additional channel of communication between the people and the Government and I am pleased to say that the public has actively made use of this channel. As at 28th February, the Unit received a total of 1,538 inputs from members of the public and 2,030 inputs from grassroots organizations as well as telephone calls and personal visits. The public is primarily concerned with issues on housing, welfare and health services, issues which touch on the daily life of Singaporeans.

    I had previously reported to this House that the members of the public were well aware that the Feedback Unit was not a complaints bureau and letters and inputs from them clearly indicated this understanding. Indeed, the private complaints and appeals which formed about 10-12% of the total inputs in March 1985 had dropped to 8% in December 1985 and only 2% in December 1986. The bulk of the inputs, that is about 50%, were suggestions and comments on national policies, while the remaining 48% were requests for information and clarification on policies. Suggestions and views from members of the public are channelled by the Unit to the various Ministries and departments for their consideration, and these Government Ministries and departments do take the feedback seriously. Changes and modifications have been made by the various Ministries and departments arising from the feedback given. Some examples are: giving longer grace

Column: 914

period for late payment of fees in view of the recession and allowing owners and occupiers of acquired land to continue with their activities if there is no immediate plan for the development of the acquired land.

    Ministries and departments are adopting a positive attitude to the feedback provided by the Unit and, wherever possible, they exercise flexibility within the constraints of broad policy guidelines. We should give them full credit for their support and cooperation which have made the task of Feedback Unit easier. Besides acting on views and suggestions from the public, the Unit also solicits views and comments from members of the public on national issues such as the National Agenda, independent schools and town councils. This is done through the various forums, dialogue sessions and informal discussions organized by the Unit with participation from professionals, grassroots organizations and individual members of the public. This year, the Unit will also hold regular dialogues with professional bodies, trade associations, social clubs and other private organizations. And I would like to take this opportunity to openly invite all interested parties and individuals who may wish to have dialogue with the Unit to get in touch with the Unit either by phone or in writing.

INVESTMENTS IN THE PEOPLE'S REPUBIC OF CHINA
BY SINGAPORE-BASED COMPANIES


    8. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) how many Singapore-based companies have invested in the People's Republic of China to date; (b) what is the level of investment committed; (c) what are the major problems faced by Singaporean investors in the PRC; and (d) whether there is an investment guarantee between the PRC and Singapore.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, some 90 Singapore-based companies have committed a total of about US$200 million in the PRC as at the end of last year.

    According to a recent survey of 50 Singapore companies, the main difficulties

Column: 915

faced by our investors in China are: the high cost of doing business, in terms of imported materials, capital equipment and workers' training; inadequate infrastructural facilities and supporting services in certain localities; identifying a suitable PRC joint venture partner since the foreign partner often bears substantial financial risks; and sourcing good quality local supplies as these are scarce and not always readily available.

    As for an investment guarantee agreement, such an agreement was signed between the PRC and Singapore in February 1986.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): Mr Chairman, Sir, when Parliament adjourned yesterday, I was commending the Government for introducing the incentive scheme for working women and I also expressed my hope that the private sector employers will follow suit. Of course, I can understand the reluctance of the employers to grant four years no-pay leave because private sector enterprises face greater uncertainty of the future than the Government as an employer. Nevertheless, I would like to see that as far as possible companies, particularly the larger ones, should keep the no- pay leave option open for the female employees.

    As regards full-pay unrecorded leave and part-time employment, I feel that this is what the private sector employers can provide. It is within the employers ability to provide such employment terms. I would like to ask the Minister for Labour what plans does the Ministry have to encourage the private sector employers to provide special incentives to the female employees similar to the ones offered by the Government.

    I would now like to turn to the question of part-time employment. While asking employers to provide part-time jobs, I would like the Minister to examine in greater depth the problem of part-time employment. Presently, there is no clear definition of what is part-time employment. The Employment Act makes no distinction between part-time and full-time employment. In other words, all the part-time and full-time employment is governed

Column: 918

by the provisions of the Employment Act. But currently, many employers are not sure whether they are obliged to grant all the benefits stipulated in the Employment Act such as annual leave, rest day and maternity leave to the part-time workers. Some feel that certain benefits are not relevant to the part-time workers. Some treat the part-time workers as temporary workers. There are abuses and some avoid paying CPF. So there is a need for the Employment Act to define clearly what is part-time work, in particular, in terms of number of hours worked per week. We have to spell out the benefits which are relevant and payable to the part-time workers. We can also specify the terms which can be subjects of negotiation between the employers and the part-time employees. While we would like to accord flexibility to the employers to engage part-time workers and make it attractive for the workers to take up part-time jobs, we must at the same time build in sufficient safeguards to check abuses.

    Sir, one of the main purposes of providing part-time job is to enable the married women who have a family commitment to take up gainful employment. It also enables people who need extra income to work part-time. But we should not relax the condition of part-time employment to the extent that the employers are induced to replace their full-time employees by part-time or temporary workers.

    Another matter which is of concern is that many employers are still reluctant to employ workers who, in their view, are too old for the job. Take the electronic industries, for instance. A number of employers are still stipulating in their advertisement that the age limit for the job of production operators is 35 or 30. Some even stipulate 28 years as the age limit.

     An hon. Member: 25 years.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: My colleague tells me 25 years. This is ridiculous. How can you consider a 25-year old person as too old? Two weeks ago, there was a photograph in the Straits Times which showed a factory assembly line in America. I think it was dated 11th March. I suggest that the

Column: 919

Minister for Labour make photocopies and distribute it to all employers. If you look at the female workers in the assembly line in America, they are at least 40-50 years old. And here in Singapore our employers want young girls aged 25-28 years. Of course, they cannot find so many young Singapore workers and so they want Malaysian workers. And they complain about the foreign worker's levy. In the meantime, our able-bodied women are staying at home. I think we must change the attitude of the employers.

    Sir, we are facing a shortage of workers in certain sectors of our economy. Our workforce is aging too. Increasingly, a larger proportion of our population are entering the age group of over 40 years old. The employers must be prepared to widen their choice and provide employment to these people. I hope the Ministry will make an effort to change the attitude of the employers and remove their bias against the older workers who, in the first place, should not be considered old.

    While still on the issue of older workers, I would like to comment on the subject of the retirement age. Sir, with an aging population, it is necessary to encourage Singaporeans to remain in the workforce beyond the age of 55. In 1986, the Economic Committee recommended two measures to encourage employers to retain their older workers.

    (1) Reduce CPF contribution rate for older workers. The Committee proposed that the CPF contribution rate be progressively reduced after the age of 45.

    (2) Encourage employers to offer part-time employment to retired workers.

    Sir, for the last 15 years, the trade unions in Singapore have been pushing hard for a raising of the retirement age. Let me give some comparative figures. The Ministry of Labour and the NTUC have made an analysis of the retirement age specified in the collective agreements signed between the employers and the unions during the period, 1972 to 1974, and for the period, 1982 to 1984. The figures have not been published but I will quote the findings.

Column: 920



    In all the collective agreements signed between the employers and the unions during the three years, 1972 to 1974, a total of 11% of the collective agreements provided for retirement age of 60 years. Largely due to the effort of the trade unions, the percentage of the collective agreements specifying retirement age of 60 was increased to 21%. This is 10 years later in the period, 1982 to 1984. But unfortunately, there has hardly been any progress in the last two years, notwithstanding the active encouragement of the Government. Recently, the Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) published its Comparative Guide to Collective Agreements, 1987. Of the 121 collective agreements signed last year, only 14% specified retirement age of 60 years, which means that there is a drop from 21% to 14%. This indicates that instead of making progress, we are sliding backwards.

    Sir, employers are unwilling to raise the retirement age. I think they are concerned about the cost of employing older workers. Perhaps they are waiting for the Government's incentives and schemes to encourage employment of older workers, such as reduction of CPF contribution rate.

    Sir, while I do not believe that it is wise to reduce the CPF contribution rate from the age of 45, I would not hesitate to support reduction of CPF contribution rate after the age of 55 if this will encourage employers to retain their workers beyond this age. I would therefore suggest that the Government makes a decision soon to reduce the CPF contribution rate for workers beyond 55 years of age, so that the employers can be encouraged to raise the retirement age to 60.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Mr Chairman, Sir, I wish to bring up a number of points on the CPF with the Minister. First, it relates to the home protection insurance scheme. This scheme has worked smoothly in providing CPF contributors and for owners of flats a convenient and painless way to insure their property. The main beneficiaries are, of course, the families of the insured. Although this scheme has worked well, I perceive that there is a weakness which may result in increased premiums to all home owners if the

Column: 921

scheme is abused. Presently, all home owners come automatically under this scheme irrespective of their medical condition. Therefore, it will be quite possible for someone who is suffering from a terminal illness to purchase a flat and get protection under this scheme. Therefore, some simple measures to regulate this potential loophole should be looked into. Otherwise, extensive abuse will affect other home owners in the way of expensive premiums.

    The other matter I wish to bring up is the CPF minimum sum topping up scheme. The details on the tax deductions allowed for this scheme were announced by the Minister for Finance in his Budget statement. That the Government has agreed to share some of the burden of providing a nest egg for a person's aged parents is in a way a major concession and admission that the Government has a role to play in taking care of the aged. However, the scheme as it stands does not ensure that the monthly sum arising from the minimum sum scheme will, in fact, go to the beneficiaries. We can only hope that those who wish to take advantage of the tax deduction will do so in the interest of their parents. The Government can only promote filial piety but it cannot ensure that this will be so.

    To emphasize this point, I suggest that in the event of premature death of a member, the balance of the minimum sum set aside under the topping up scheme should be subject to tax. It is tax free. The balance due to premature death should be subject to tax. I hope the Minister will review this argument with the Minister for Finance.

    The last point I wish to bring up is the long term CPF contribution rate. In the days when the CPF contribution rate was increasing as fast as NWC wage recommendations, there were complaints from contributors that the Government was taking away, with the right hand, what it was giving to the employees with the left hand. I think during this period, employees chose to believe that the CPF was not their money. It was locked up by the Government. After being told repeatedly that CPF savings are, in fact, their money, I think they have come to accept this. They have also found a way to empty this untouc-

Column: 922

hable pizza. The thinking is that since this money cannot be made available at will, one might as well commit it fully to a flat or a house. "Never mind whether or not a 3-room flat is sufficient for the family. Let us upgrade." Everybody wants to upgrade. That is the password. The HDB responded with a zeal. They built more and better homes. However, upgrading as we know has its cost. It over-commits a person and his family to one major investment. To my mind, there is no doubt that this over-commitment to house/mortgage repayments was a key factor in the resistance against the cut in CPF last year. Nothing generates a more defensive mechanism than a flat to family and home. In fact, the main point of the debate on the cut in CPF last year centred on housing.

    Sir, now that we moved the CPF rate down, the Minister must use this opportunity to take a completely fresh and even radical look at what is termed as a long term rate of CPF. Having moved away last year from the old rate of 50% and maimed all contributors psychologically, I think it is not useful to speak of the long term rate of CPF as if there is such a rate, which is in fact sacrosanct.

    Personally, the Minister would do well to dampen such an expectation. A long term rate is one which, in fact, is what the market can bear. If the market can bear, therefore, there is no such thing as a fixed and long term rate. The CPF rate must, in itself, not be too rigid. So far the rigidity is one way, that is, a reduction calls for much debate. It must be sufficiently flexible to allow for short term responses to the economic difficulties. At the same time, contributors must have some assurance that they will always have a sufficient level of contribution to meet their present needs on housing and their basic needs in the future.

    To have both these features, I suggest there should be a fixed or base rate. At the same time there should be a flexible rate of CPF contribution. Conveniently, the fixed rate should be the present rate of 35%. Any upward adjustments made to the CPF should be considered as a flexible portion. The rate paid into this flexible portion can be changed or altered at will. By designating this as a flexible com-

Column: 923

ponent enables two benefits. Firstly, the rate may be varied for different salary levels. This is not new or radical as there exists a ceiling on both the upper and lower ends at this time. There could be compelling reasons for this possibility in the event that the need to emphasize or de-emphasize certain economic activity arises. It may even be useful if you wish to achieve certain social objectives. Secondly, with this flexible component, we can respond more readily to meet any economic exigencies that may arise. The recession of 1985 is a good case in point. With this component not committed to housing, any reduction or suspension of this portion will generate less heat and debate.
